item.title: Testing Angular Apps with Jasmine and Karma
item.dc:creator: Bob at Genuitec
item.description:
Testing is one of the most important aspects of the modern application development process. Today, high quality, robust applications are the norm; nobody appreciates a buggy application. This article will walk you through testing your Angular application using capabilities that are already part of your Angular project.Creating a New Angular ProjectWe’re going to be using […]

The post Testing Angular Apps with Jasmine and Karma appeared first on Genuitec.

item.title: Set Up and Use a Fake REST API with Angular
item.dc:creator: Bob at Genuitec
item.description:
Often, when developing Angular applications, you do not have the backing REST APIs ready for testing. To avoid having to digress into developing web services, or being blocked, waiting for your back end team to provide them, you can use JSON server to provide a “fake” API. This article will show you how to use […]

The post Set Up and Use a Fake REST API with Angular appeared first on Genuitec.

item.title: Angular 5 Features
item.dc:creator: Brian Fernandes
item.description:
Front-end developers, rejoice – after a short delay, the Angular 5 release is scheduled for October 23rd!Update (October 27th): Unfortunately, Angular 5 hasn’t been released yet – the latest release in this stream is 5.0.0 RC 7, which was released earlier today. However, we’re sure the release is right around the corner … watch this space […]

The post Angular 5 Features appeared first on Genuitec.

item.title: Using Swagger to Connect a Backend to an Angular Frontend
item.dc:creator: Brian Fernandes
item.category: connect front end to back end
connecting front end to back end
item.description:
IntroductionLet’s say you have an advanced backend system, for which you wish to develop a modern Angular frontend, or, perhaps it’s not your backend, but something public like Facebook, and you want to develop a site using some of its exposed APIs. Of course, you want to do this with minimal effort … how do […]

The post Using Swagger to Connect a Backend to an Angular Frontend appeared first on Genuitec.

item.title: Working with Java 9 in Eclipse
item.dc:creator: Brian Fernandes
item.description:
Note: This blog was updated on October 11th, 2017 to reflect the release of Oxygen 1a which includes Java 9 support.The Java 9 GA release is just a few weeks old, and you can start developing with Java 9 in Eclipse, right now! All you need to do is download a suitable Oxygen 1a (4.7.1a) […]

item.title: JavaOne 2017: Highlights
item.dc:creator: Brian Fernandes
item.description:
In his keynote at the JavaOne Conference, James Governor said, “Things have changed in the Java ecosystem, probably more in the past three weeks, than they have in the previous thirteen years.” Now JavaOne has only just ended, and we’re still trying to sift through the vast volumes of information pouring out from this conference, […]

The post JavaOne 2017: Highlights appeared first on Genuitec.

item.title: Code Sharing Evolving
item.dc:creator: Wanda Muriy
item.description:
Is there a little code snippet that is just driving you crazy? Or would you like a detailed collaborative session even before you dive in? There are different ways of sharing your code to get another developer to get involved. Read on for more!Simply Share with SlackSo how can you share your code? One easy […]

item.title: Hackathons Going Virtual with CodeTogether
item.dc:creator: Wanda Muriy
item.description:
In the coding world, collaboration has been taking place in the form of coding parties, retreats or hackathons, and, more recently, through new technologies that allow for virtual exchanges. Many might argue long and hard, giving preference to one over the other, but what’s the deal behind each one? Partying ‘developer-style’The word “party” normally conjures up […]

The post Hackathons Going Virtual with CodeTogether appeared first on Genuitec.

item.title: TypeScript 2.4 — Even More Reasons to Love it!
item.dc:creator: Wanda Muriy
item.description:
Perhaps you are already enjoying all the amazing features TypeScript (TS) adds to JavaScript: you might already be in love with its interfaces, abstract classes, and algebraic data types, among many others. TS 2.4 brings more good news. This version of TS comes loaded with improvements, ranging from dynamic import expressions to weak type detection.ModulesNeed […]

item.title: 2017 CI 8 Keeps Adding to the Treasure Chest
item.dc:creator: Wanda Muriy
item.description:
Good news – our new release is out the door! For Angular IDE and Webclipse, we give you access to a brand new Eclipse experience with our DevStyle Preview. MyEclipse includes some key bug fixes in the Spring / Maven project area, and a new version of the Eclipse Buildship toolset, for improved Gradle support. […]

item.title: Equifax Data Breach Advisory
item.dc:creator: Brian Fernandes
item.description:
Many of you may have heard of the Equifax data breach, possibly affecting millions of consumers. Information accessed by hackers during the incident included Social Security numbers, personal details, driver’s license numbers, and even credit card numbers.Equifax has confirmed that the breach was made possible by a vulnerability in the Apache Struts Web Framework, used […]

The post Equifax Data Breach Advisory appeared first on Genuitec.

item.title: Creating a Bus Fare Comparison App with Angular 4 and Node.js
item.dc:creator: Bob at Genuitec
item.description:
In this Angular tutorial, you will learn how to create an app to compare bus fares. We will be using Angular IDE to create our application, which will fetch bus fare data using goibibo’s web services.Creating a New Angular ProjectIn the new Angular project wizard, enter BusFareCompare as the project name. We used Angular CLI […]

item.title: Editors vs IDEs — What’s Best for You?
item.dc:creator: Wanda Muriy
item.description:
Life is full of choices and dilemmas, and for a developer one of the greatest queries is whether to use a text editor or an Integrated Development Environment (IDE).  Of course, using the latter provides for a much more complete experience, and yet, it might not be an absolute must in all situations. But how […]

item.title: Building Applications with Angular Material
item.dc:creator: Bob at Genuitec
item.description:
Angular Material is a set of high-quality UI components developed by the Angular team, based on the Google Material design specification. These components help us to build applications with an attractive, yet familiar UI, giving users a consistent experience across devices.In this Angular tutorial, you will learn how to set up material design in your […]

item.title: SDC 2017 SR2 – Software Delivery Evolving Further
item.dc:creator: Wanda Muriy
item.description:
